newsitem.title: LIBYA: Five Saharan countries agree to economic tie-up.
newsitem.headline: Five Saharan countries agree to economic tie-up.

text.p: Libya, Niger, Chad, Mali and Burkina Faso have agreed to set up an economic regional grouping at a summit in Tripoli, a group spokesman said on Saturday.

"The five heads of states have reached a decision favouring closer ties between their countries and have instructed their foreign affairs ministers to discuss practical ways for its implementation," Niger's Foreign Affairs Minister Ibrahim Assane Mayaki told journalists.
He said the idea was to set up a regional economic grouping within the framework of the Organisation of African Unity.

The foreign ministers of the five African countries, who met on Saturday, will meet in early September to discuss mechanisms for such a grouping ahead of a second summit likely to be held later that month, Mayaki said.
He added Nigeria would also be invited to join the group. Nigeria's military ruler Sani Abacha missed the Tripoli summit due to ill health, said Mayaki.
Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi proposed the grouping on Friday night during a three-hour closed meeting with heads of states from the visiting countries.
Gaddafi suggested Tunisia, Algeria, Morocco, Mauritania and Egypt also be invited to join the grouping.
Gaddafi also proposed that Libya open its ports to the land-locked African countries giving them access to the Mediterranean.
But diplomats said that such a project would necessitate important investments in roads through the Sahara and it was not yet clear how they would be financed.
